# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)
import cv2 as cv
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import cv2

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

cat = cv2.imread('../input/catsdogs/cats_and_dogs_filtered/train/cats/cat.10.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
woman = cv2.imread('../input/beauty-detection-data-set/consolidated/beautiful/0004.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
dog = cv2.imread('../input/catsdogs/cats_and_dogs_filtered/validation/dogs/dog.2001.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
aWoman = cv2.imread('../input/beauty-detection-data-set/consolidated/average/0003.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
#industry = cv2.imread('../input/cv-images/industry-min.png', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
#finance = cv2.imread('../input/cv-images/finance-min.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)

plt.figure(figsize=(40, 30))
plt.subplot(2, 2, 1).set_title('Cat', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(cat, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2, 2, 2).set_title('Beautiful', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(woman, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2, 2, 3).set_title('Dog', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(dog, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2, 2, 4).set_title('Average???', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(aWoman, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
#plt.subplot(3, 2, 5).set_title('Industry', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
#plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(industry, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
#plt.subplot(3, 2, 6).set_title('Finance', fontsize = 65); plt.axis('off')   
#plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(finance, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.suptitle('Applications of Computer Vision', fontsize = 60)
plt.show()

plt.figure(figsize=(15, 8))
for i, path in enumerate(paths):
    
    name = os.path.split(path)[-1]
    img = cv2.imread(path, cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
    resized_img = cv2.resize(img, (height, width))
    
    plt.subplot(1, 2, i+1).set_title(name[ : -4], fontsize = font_size); plt.axis('off')
    plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(resized_img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.show()
source.3bad7d94:
#Code by Asha Gutlapalli https://www.kaggle.com/ashagutlapalli/computer-vision-101-with-opencv/notebook

R = cv2.imread('../input/catsdogs/cats_and_dogs_filtered/train/cats/cat.10.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
R = cv2.resize(R, (224, 224))
H = cv2.imread('../input/beauty-detection-data-set/consolidated/beautiful/0004.jpg', cv2.IMREAD_COLOR)
H = cv2.resize(H, (224, 224))

G = R.copy()
guassian_pyramid_c = [G]
for i in range(6):
    G = cv2.pyrDown(G)
    guassian_pyramid_c.append(G)
 
     
G = H.copy()
guassian_pyramid_d = [G]
for i in range(6):
    G = cv2.pyrDown(G)
    guassian_pyramid_d.append(G)

laplacian_pyramid_c = [guassian_pyramid_c[5]]
for i in range(5, 0, -1):
    GE = cv2.pyrUp(guassian_pyramid_c[i])
    L = cv2.subtract(guassian_pyramid_c[i-1], GE)
    laplacian_pyramid_c.append(L)

laplacian_pyramid_d = [guassian_pyramid_d[5]]
for i in range(5,0,-1):
    guassian_expanded = cv2.pyrUp(guassian_pyramid_d[i])
    L = cv2.subtract(guassian_pyramid_d[i-1], guassian_expanded)
    laplacian_pyramid_d.append(L)

laplacian_joined = []
for lc,ld in zip(laplacian_pyramid_c, laplacian_pyramid_d):
    r, c, d = lc.shape
    lj = np.hstack((lc[:, 0 : int(c / 2)], ld[:, int(c / 2) :]))
    laplacian_joined.append(lj)

laplacian_reconstructed = laplacian_joined[0]
for i in range(1,6):
    laplacian_reconstructed = cv2.pyrUp(laplacian_reconstructed)
    laplacian_reconstructed = cv2.add(laplacian_reconstructed, laplacian_joined[i])

direct = np.hstack((R[ : , : int(c / 2)], H[ : , int(c / 2) : ]))

plt.figure(figsize=(30, 20))
plt.subplot(2,2,1).set_title('Cat', fontsize = 35); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(R, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2,2,2).set_title('Woman', fontsize = 35); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(H, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2,2,3).set_title('CatWoman Joining', fontsize = 35); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(direct, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.subplot(2,2,4).set_title('Pyramid Blending', fontsize = 35); plt.axis('off')   
plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(laplacian_reconstructed, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
plt.show()

source.29baf293:
#"In 1975 Persona Game was presented at the 13th Art Bienal of São Paulo. The same mirror was used, only two people played at a time, interacting with each other."

![](https://ogimg.infoglobo.com.br/in/25019257-ad9-a24/FT1086A/x92831983_SC-15-08-2018-Cena-do-jogo-Persona-do-artista-italiano-Roberto-Campadello-que-inspirou-o-di.jpg.pagespeed.ic.OUwVUAHfOP.jpg)oglobo.oglobo.com
source.29d83beb: In 1973 PERSONA was made with Mirrors. Now, PERSONA with Computer Vision.
source.2e9d1cd7:
PERSONA The Mutations Game with Mirrors

"In 1972 Roberto Campadello, an Italian plastic artist, has an insight with a friend who owns a glass factory and they invent a special mirror. When Campadello and his friend carried one of the mirrors together, they realized that their faces merged, forming a single face. Roberto then makes a project for the 12th São Paulo International Arts Biennial, in 1973. The project was called Casa Dourada, due to the color of the mirror." "Casa Dourada was an octagon formed by special mirrors, where visitors to the Bienal would see themselves mixed together and mixed in the mixtures of each other. The project was approved at the 1973, 1975 and 1977 Biennials. During the event, Roberto stayed inside the House, distributing candles and taking visitors to the sensory experiences caused by mirrors. It was in the meantime that " Persona " was born ." "In 1977, another sensorial installation formed by special mirrors is presented to the public at the 14th International Biennial of Arts in São Paulo." https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=http://historiafotopersonabh.blogspot.com/2011/05/em-1972-roberto-campadello-artista.html&prev=search&pto=aue
source.b44f1af1:
#Persona Disc - with the Songs to play.

"In the second half of the 1980s, Campadello started photographing his bar's customers playing Persona and developed a photographic technique to capture the images. At the same time, Roberto received the proposal from Grow (toy manufacturer) to produce the Persona Game on a large scale. Roberto goes to the United States and the “Persona Game” begins to be commercialized. The Game consisted of a Persona mirror, a pair of candles and candlestick and a Persona disc - with the songs to play. Failing to reach a satisfactory agreement with the company, Roberto stops the production of the Game and returns to Brazil. About a thousand Games were produced and marketed at that time. Today the Game and the Disc are regarded as relics - the Persona disc is the third rarest disc in the world."

https://translate.google.com.br/translate?hl=en&sl=pt&u=http://historiafotopersonabh.blogspot.com/2011/05/em-1972-roberto-campadello-artista.html&prev=search&pto=aue
